Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff choked a youth.
Investigation On 8/12/24 the agency self-reported an allegation that Youth A
was choked by Staff 1 on 8/10/24. There is video footage of the
incident. Staff 1 allegedly held Youth A by her neck and threw
someone’s personal items around the wing. Youth A sustained
minor bruising and scratching on her biceps and wrists, in addition
to an abrasion on the left side of her chin. Youth A reported pain in
her left wrist.
Face-to-face contact occurred with Complainant on-site, on
8/13/24. Complainant did not have any additional information, as
they did not witness the incident.
Youth A was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported she, “hates it here”. Youth A
would not identify anything she liked about the placement. Youth
A stated she was being abused by staff. When asked for more
information, Youth A stated that staff restrain kids, and she knew
they were not allowed to. It was clarified for Youth A that restraint
is allowed, but it must be done properly to follow state
requirements. Youth A stated discipline consists of being
restricted to the wing, losing television privilege, and not going on
outings. Youth A stated she did not feel safe at the facility
because they give them food that is “disgusting”. Youth A clarified
she meant they use canned food, which she did not like. Youth A
stated staff do not let her sleep in which affects her “beauty sleep”.
Regarding the alleged incident, Youth A stated Staff 1 choked her
until she could not breathe. Youth A stated staff were hitting her
and restraining her when she did not want to be touched. Youth A
stated that Staff 4, Staff 5 and Staff 8 restrained her by holding her
arms. Youth A stated she tried to fight back but could not break
loose. Youth A said nothing else happened after the restraint, but
she had two scratches on her jaw, and scratches on her upper
2

arms. Youth A was unsure of how the scratches occurred. Youth
A reported she saw a nurse after the incident.
Youth A stated Staff 1 did not typically work on her wing. Youth A
said she could not recall what happened prior to Staff 1 choking
her. She stated she remembered peers being upset because
Youth E sprayed Staff 9 with something she was allergic to, and it
made her sick. Youth A stated Staff 4 kept Youth D locked in her
room during this time also. These two events were what caused
the wing to riot.
Youth B was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Youth B stated that staff were abusive and did
not listen to the youth. Youth B did not like anything about the
placement. Youth B reported when youth get in trouble, their
activities are restricted. Youth B stated she did not feel safe there
but would not explain why. Youth B stated the food is terrible,
because they serve vegetables she does not like. Youth B
reported she had two bruises on her arms, from staff pushing her
into her room on 8/10/24.Youth B reported she also had a large
bruise on her upper thigh but did not show DCWL and DHHS
Workers. Youth B was not sure which staff caused the bruises.
Regarding the allegation, Youth B stated that all of the youth were
upset that night because Youth E sprayed something in Staff 9’s
eyes. The youth “flipped out” and ended up getting arrested for
throwing things all over the wing and at staff. Youth B stated five
youth got arrested and taken to the hospital around 6:30PM. The
youth were all sent back to the facility around 8:00PM. Around
10:00PM the youth decided to have a sleep over in the living
room, although staff told them not to. Youth moved cushions,
pillows and blankets into the middle of the floor. Staff were
removing the items. Youth B began swearing and threatening
staff. Youth B then slapped one of the staff but could not recall
which one. Youth B was placed in a restraint. After the restraint
she was instructed to go to her room but refused. Youth D was
forced into her room and kept there by staff. Youth B could not
recall which staff. However, Youth B remembered trying to force
her way into the room to let Youth D out. Youth B stated she also
believed that Youth A was choked by staff, although she did not
know which staff as she did not see it happen. Youth B reported
being restrained by staff for ‘no reason’ on two prior occasions.
Youth D reported seeing a nurse after every restraint. However,
after the interview, her file and restraint reports were reviewed, it
was determined that Youth B had not been restrained previously.
3

Youth C was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Youth C stated that the facility was “okay” and
there were some staff that were nicer than others. Youth C stated
that when kids get in trouble they are restricted to the wing and
are unable do other activities on campus. Youth C said she felt
unsafe at times as staff, “tend to hit kids”. Youth C was unable to
provide an example of when this happened.
Regarding the allegation, Youth C stated Staff 9 was having
trouble breathing after Youth E sprayed some perfume at her. All
of the youth started “freaking out”, breaking things, yelling,
throwing things, trying to break windows, and trying to break the
door down. Then the police arrived, arrested five youth, and took
them to the hospital. When they returned from the hospital that
night around 10:00PM, everyone refused to go to their rooms.
Youth piled their pillows and blankets on the floor in the living
room. Staff then took the pillows and blankets. Youth became
upset and started acting out again. Staff 4 locked Youth D in her
room, but no one knew why. Youth A then got snacks from
somewhere and passed them out to her peers. Staff chased Youth
A, trying to get the snacks from her. Youth A went to the door,
kicked it several times, and threatened staff. Youth C stated she
did not see it, but she was told that Staff 1 hit Youth A in the face
and choked her. She was also told an unknown staff hit Youth B.
Youth C stated things eventually calmed down and everyone went
to their rooms. Youth C was not given her blanket back that night,
but she was provided with another blanket.
Youth D was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Youth D reported she was unhappy with her
placement and did not like any staff. Youth D stated that when
youth are in trouble, they are placed on restriction and cannot
leave the wing to go to activities. Youth D sated she did not feel
safe there because of what her peers were doing on 8/10/24.
Youth D stated that she did not see anything, as she was in her
room. Youth D reported she was misbehaving, going in and out of
other people’s bedrooms, when one staff stood in her room and
asked her to stay in there. The door was open, but staff were
encouraging her to stay put, while the other youth were acting out
in the living room. Youth D was in her room with staff at her door
for approximately 15 minutes. Youth D stated she could hear
Youth A yelling but did not see anything.
Youth E was not interviewed, as she was not present on the wing
when the alleged incident occurred. Youth E resided on another
wing. The incident between Youth E and Staff 9, which allegedly
4

angered Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D, occurred on
another wing and was not witnessed by these youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 recalled that she was working on 8/10/24
and arrived on shift at 7:00pm. The youth had already been
removed from the building by law enforcement. Staff 2 was not
assigned to the wing but assisted in straightening up the mess
that was made prior to her arrival. Around 9:00pm the youth
arrived back at the facility. Staff tried to get them to settle in for
bed, but Youth A and Youth D were screaming, yelling, and
swearing. Staff on duty were encouraging the youth to quiet down
and talk about what was upsetting them. Staff 2 had to leave the
wing at that point, as another youth was returning from the
hospital and needed to be placed in a different wing, due to the
earlier conflict. Around 9:30PM Staff 2 returned to the wing and
found that the youth had been drawing with markers all over the
doors and walls. Youth A, Youth B and Youth D were being loud
and keeping the other youth up. Staff 2 took a few youth, who
wanted to sleep, to another wing. When Staff 2 returned, some of
the girls had piled cushions, pillows and blankets on the living
room floor, and declared they were not going to go in their rooms.
Some of the youth made comments about attacking staff. Some
youth were kicking doors and going in and out of peer’s
bedrooms. Staff were following the youth to keep an eye on what
they were doing, and verbally directing them to stop. At one point
Youth A took Staff 1’s lunch and ran around the room. Youth A
attacked one staff, while Staff 2 held Youth B, Youth C and Youth
D back by holding her arms out and talking with them. Staff 2 did
not see anyone restrain Youth A or Youth B.
Eventually Law Enforcement arrived again. Youth D was removed
from the wing for attempting to self-harm. Youth B calmed down
and went to her room, Youth C decided to go to bed, Youth A was
removed from the wing as she seemed to be the instigator. Once
everyone was calm, staff cleaned up the wing.
Staff 3 was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she worked the morning and
afternoon shift on 8/10/24. Staff 3 assisted on the wing after the
team leader (Staff 9) had an asthma attack. When Staff 3 arrived
on the wing to help Staff 9, some of youth were in an altercation.
Staff 3 was in the office waiting for paramedics and did not see
any restraints or incidents between staff and youth on the wing.
5

Staff 1 was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 confirmed working on 8/10/24 from 3-
11:30PM. Staff 1 stated this was her normal shift, but not her
normal building. When Staff 1 arrived on C wing, it was “chaos”.
The youth were yelling, swearing, kicking doors, and tearing
things apart. Staff were trying to verbally redirect them, but it was
not working. Law Enforcement arrived and restrained several of
the girls, then placed them in handcuffs. The youth were
belligerent and physical with the officers, while they attempted to
secure everyone. Most of the youth were removed by the officers.
However, the youth returned to the facility a few hours later. When
they returned, staff tried to get them to go to bed. But the youth
continued to act out and refused to cooperate. Youth A refused
her medication. The girls were walking around the wing yelling
profanity and telling staff they did not need to follow the rules.
Youth were taking things off the walls and destroying everything
they could. Additional staff came on to the wing to assist. Staff 1
recalled Youth A grabbed her lunch and began throwing it around
the room. Staff 1 tried to verbally redirect Youth A, but she would
not listen. Staff 1 tried to pull the bag from Youth A’s hands, by
grabbing Youth A’s wrists for a few seconds and telling her to stop
what she was doing. Youth A then tried to bite Staff 1. Staff 1
placed her hand on the back of Youth A’s neck in an attempt to
keep her from biting. Staff 1 stated she was aware this was not
part of CPI training. Staff 1 denied choking or grabbing Youth A in
any other way. Staff 1 stated she held Youth A for a few seconds
before Staff 3 instructed Staff 1 to release her.
Youth A then tried to tear down ceiling tiles, break windows, and
broke the wing phone. A “clear” was called for all youth to go to
their rooms. However, the youth stated they were “bad b******”
and going to do what they wanted. Youth then began piling couch
cushions, blankets, and pillows on the floor. One staff began
removing the blankets and pillows from the area. Youth A grabbed
Staff 4 by the hair and started kicking her. Two staff took Youth
A’s arms and placed her in a standing hold. Staff 1 tried to assist
by grabbing Youth A’s ankles. However, Staff 4 told her to let go,
as it was not correct. Staff 1 stepped away from the restraint, as
the other staff had it under control. Staff 1 was unsure which staff
were part of the restraint. Law Enforcement then arrived on-site
again.
Staff 1 stated that none of the kids were locked in their rooms.
Youth D was in her room during the situation, with staff talking to
her, trying to get her to calm down.
6

Staff 1 did not see any staff grab or choke Youth A. Staff 1 did not
see any staff grab or hit any youth. Staff 1 did not see any staff
restrain Youth B.
Staff 4 was interviewed on-site, on 8/13/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. Staff 4 was not scheduled to work on 8/10/24 but
came in to support the wing due to some behavior issues. Staff 4
arrived around 7:30PM. There were several police officers on
site, removing five kids from the wing. Staff 4 observed there was
a lot of damage to the wing. The officers took the youth to a
hospital nearby. Staff 4 went to the hospital to drop off staff for
additional support with the youth. An hour later, all five of the
youth returned to the facility. Staff 4 observed the youth were
getting riled up again and had moved the couch cushions to the
floor and piled blankets and pillows on top. Kids were running in
and out of bedrooms, attempting to barricade themselves in. Staff
removed items from rooms to prevent any barricading. Staff
escorted kids out of Youth D’s bedroom. Staff 4 went into Youth
D’s room to talk with her and encourage her not to get involved in
what the other girls were doing. Staff 4 stood in the doorway of
Youth D’s room with Staff 5. Youth D was slowly deescalating.
However, the other youth were trying to push their way into the
room and yelling at staff. Staff 4 was standing outside of the door,
holding it open, to avoid having the door slammed on anyone.
Kids began hitting Staff 4’s arm. Youth D started to walk forward,
and Staff 4 warned her not to put her hands on any staff. Youth D
stopped moving and stayed in her room. Youth D could have
walked out of her room at any time. No one was holding her or the
door, to prevent her from leaving.
When Staff 4 walked out of the room, Youth A was being
physically managed by staff. Staff 4 tried to assist, but Youth A bit,
kicked and pulled her hair. Youth A was “tussling” to get out of the
restraint, while staff tried to release Staff 4’s hair from Youth A’s
grasp. Staff 4 did not observe any issues or inappropriate actions
during the restraint. Staff 4 did not see anyone choke Youth A.
After the restraint, Staff 4 spent 30-40 minutes talking to Youth A.
Youth A was able to deescalate at that time and have a
conversation.
Staff 4 denied any restraint of Youth B by staff. However, Staff 4
was aware that law enforcement really struggled to handcuff the
youth and restrained some of them.
Staff 5 was interviewed on-site, on 8/10/24, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Staff 5 reported that her shift ended, prior to
7

anything happening on the wing. However, she returned later to
assist. When Staff 5 arrived, law enforcement had already been
on-site once. Around 9:00PM the youth returned from the hospital.
Some of them wanted to go to bed, others refused. Some youth
took blankets, sheets, and pillows into the living room. Youth tried
to move their mattresses off their beds, but staff were able to stop
them. When the youth started putting couch cushions on the floor,
staff intervened and removed the cushions. At that point, the girls
started running in and out of bedrooms. They were riled up and
arguing with staff. Staff tried to talk with youth and encourage
them to make good choices, but they were not listening. Staff 5
went to Youth D’s bedroom and encouraged her to stay there, to
avoid getting in trouble with the other girls. Staff 5 stated Youth D
was not locked in her room or kept in there by staff. Staff 5 noted
that they are physically unable to lock the bedroom doors.
When Staff 5 left the room, Youth A was trying to punch staff and
had ahold of Staff 4’s hair. Youth A was placed in a restraint by
staff. Staff 5 did not see anything unusual or inappropriate about
the restraint. Staff 5 did not see anyone’s hands near Youth A’s
neck. Staff 5 did not recall anyone restraining Youth B.
Staff 6 was interviewed via video call, on 8/14/24, in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 6 recalled being present when law
enforcement came onto the wing. Officers placed five youth in
handcuffs, due to their out of control and violent behavior. Youth A
was restrained by officers after trying to assault one of them. The
youth were then taken to the hospital but returned to the facility a
few hours later. When they returned, youth were “trashing” the
wing. Youth A was taunting staff, taking staff belongings, and
writing in marker all over the floor and walls. Youth A was
assaultive toward staff, but staff did not initially restrain. Staff 6
had to leave the wing briefly. Upon returning, Staff 6 observed
Staff 1 holding Youth A’s wrists, crisscrossed in front of her. Staff
6 and Staff 8 stepped in to assist, and informed Staff 1 that her
hold was not correct. Staff 6 and Staff 8 placed Youth A in a
standing hold, by each holding one of her arms. Youth A dropped
her weight to the floor and staff released her arms. Youth A was
yelling and encouraging peers to act out. Staff 2 and Staff 4 tried
to assist in talking with Youth A to calm her down. However, Youth
A began attacking Staff 4 by pulling her hair, while kicking at other
staff. When staff tried to intervene Youth A tried to bite them. Staff
then placed Youth A in a standing hold. Staff 6 did not recall
seeing Staff 1 or any other staff put their hand on or near Youth
A’s neck. Staff 6 recalled hearing Youth A yell that she could not
8

breathe. Staff immediately released her from the restraint, despite
not seeing any reason why her breathing would be affected.
Staff 6 did not see any youth locked in their rooms. Youth D was
in her room with Staff 4 and Staff 5, talking for some time as they
were trying to calm her down. But Youth D was not locked in her
room. Staff 6 did not recall seeing Youth B restrained.
Staff 7 was interviewed via video call on 8/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 7 reported working on another wing on
8/10/24. While on that wing, Youth E pulled down ceiling tiles and
internet cables from the ceiling. Youth E stood on the staff desk,
attempting to put the cables around her neck. Staff 7 got on the
desk and removed the cord. Youth E then broke the wing phone,
spit on, and threatened staff. Staff 9 then had an asthma attack
and an ambulance needed to be called.
The youth from another wing saw through a window that Staff 9
was on the floor and became upset with Youth E, as they felt she
did something to Staff 9. Staff 7 went onto that wing to try to calm
the youth down. However, Youth A and Youth D were standing on
the desk screaming they would destroy everything. Several of the
youth began throwing things around the wing, banging on doors,
and breaking items. Staff 7 called for additional assistance. Staff 1
came onto the wing, while Staff 7 stepped out to check on the
situation with Youth E. Staff 7 observed Staff 9 in the office with
another staff, waiting for an ambulance.
When Staff 7 returned to the wing, there were three additional
staff from other wings that came to assist, along with Law
Enforcement. Youth B was handcuffed and sitting in the hallway.
Staff 7 spoke with Youth B to calm her down, as she was scared.
Staff 7 also observed that officers restrained Youth A, Youth D,
and Youth F. Officers then went to the other wing for Youth E.
Youth E fought with officers, but they were able to place her in
handcuffs. The youth were transported to the hospital. However,
hospital staff were “fed up” with the girls insulting and swearing at
them. Hospital staff asked the girls if they had any thoughts of
self-harm. When the girls answered “no”, they were discharged
back to the facility.
When they arrived at the facility, the youth refused to go to bed. It
was around 9:00PM, which is their bedtime. Youth A and Youth B
brought pillows and blankets into the living room and refused to go
to their rooms. Youth A then grabbed some markers and began
drawing all over herself, the walls, and the doors. Staff 7 tried to
9

ignore the behavior, hoping Youth A would get bored with it and
go to bed. Staff 4 and Staff 5 arrived on the wing and tried to talk
with the girls. Staff 6 attempted to follow the routine and give the
youth their meds for the night, but they refused. Youth A continued
to escalate. Youth D began to escalate, but Staff 4 and Staff 5
went into her room and spoke with her, to convince her not to start
acting up again with Youth A. Youth A and Youth B went in and
out of peer rooms, even though they know they were not
supposed to. Youth A was upset that staff were talking with Youth
D in her room and began yelling to let Youth D out. Youth A
charged at Staff 4. Staff 4 put her arm out to block Youth A from
entering Youth D’s room. Youth A then went to the staff desk and
grabbed Staff 1’s lunch, then tried to charge at staff again. Staff 1
grabbed Youth A’s wrists briefly, but Staff 7 instructed her not to.
Staff 6, Staff 5, and Staff 4 intervened and attempted a standing
hold with Youth A. However, Youth A was kicking, biting, and
pulling away from staff. Youth A then dropped to the floor, still
kicking at staff. Staff moved away and gave Youth A space. Staff
7 then left the wing and returned to her assigned wing. Staff 7
stated that she never saw any staff choke or grab Youth A by the
neck. Only Youth A’s arms were held by staff. Staff 7 also
reported that Youth D was never locked in her room. The door
was partially shut for privacy while Staff 4 and Staff 5 were talking
with her. Staff 7 did not see anyone restrain Youth B.
Staff 8 was interviewed via video call on 8/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 8 reported that she was assigned to
another wing on 8/10/24 but responded to a call for assistance.
When she arrived, the girls were writing on walls, yelling profanity,
and refusing to go to bed. Staff 8 attempted to talk with the girls
and encourage them to calm down. But they did not want to listen
to her. The girls wanted to have a sleep over in the living room but
were told that was not allowed. So, they continued running
around, yelling, swearing, laughing and dancing. Staff 4 arrived on
the wing and told staff to move the pile of pillows and blankets out
of the living room. Staff 8 assisted with this task. The girls then
went in and out of one another’s rooms, even though they were
aware that was not allowed. Staff 8 stated she had difficulty
recalling details after that. Staff 8 did not recall seeing any youth
locked in a room. Staff 8 saw Youth A restrained by staff, after she
was pulling Staff 4’s hair. Staff 8 did not see anyone choking or
holding the youth near her neck. Staff 8 recalled at one point that
Youth A grabbed Staff 1’s personal belongings and began
throwing them around. Staff 1 became upset and started yelling.
Staff 8 told Staff 1 to “tap out” and step away. Staff 8 said this
three times, before Staff 1 walked away. After things calmed
10

down, Youth A reported she was hurt by someone, but did not
know who, and did not provide any further details.
Staff 9 was not interviewed, as she was away from the building
and did not witness anything due to the medical emergency that
occurred prior to the alleged incident.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted via video call on
9/10/24. FCW reported she had no concerns about the care Youth
A received at the facility. FCW reported that Youth A had been
increasingly escalated and was at the hospital for evaluation at the
time of the call. FCW attributed her escalated behavior to be due
to personal events happening in her life, outside of the facility.
FCW reported that a discussion occurred with Youth A about
being truthful, after telling Youth A that the video showed no one
had choked her.
Video reviewed:
• Video from 8/10/24 was reviewed. The video was
consistent with information reported by staff. However, it
was difficult to fully see the interaction between Youth A
and Staff 1 due to the video quality.
The video did not show a restraint of Youth B, or staff
pushing her into a room.
The video showed Youth D in her room with staff, with the
door ajar.
• A second video of the wing was reviewed. This video was
filmed during the time Law Enforcement was there. The
video was very dark which made it difficult to see
specifically what occurred. However, it was noted that
officers restrained youth to the ground.
Documents reviewed:
• The Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1
was hired 6/26/24, attended Orientation 6/27/24, and
completed CPI training 7/10/24. Staff 1 did not have any
disciplinary action on file prior to this incident.
• Police report dated 8/10/24 regarding Youth A. The verified
offense was inciting a riot and non-aggravated assault. The
report indicated officers were dispatched to the facility due
to youth “rioting” and destroying the “wings”. The report
was consistent with information from staff, regarding the
youth behavior.
• A body chart for Youth A, dated 8/10/24, indicated
scratches on the youth’s shoulders, upper arms, and belly.
Youth A reported three other marks: handcuff mark on her
11

left wrist, a bruise on her left kneed from the police, and a
bruise on her right knee from the hospital.
• A nursing note dated 8/12/24 (9:45AM) indicated the visit
was follow-up for Youth A’s reported left wrist pain after
being restrained on 8/10/24. Youth A had full range of
motion, no swelling, and no bruising. Youth A had a small
bruise on her forearm. When asked if it was old or new,
Youth A became upset, yelling, and refused to complete
the assessment.
• A nursing note dated 8/12/24 (3:30PM) indicated Youth A
complained of pain in her left wrist since the “incident” with
police. Youth A stated she was held face down on the
ground. Youth A reported she was not sure if she sprained
her wrist but had multiple wrist sprains on both sides in her
past. As the exam continues, Youth A complained of pain in
her right wrist, stating it bothered her more than the left
wrist. Youth A then stated she was not sure which wrist
hurt, indicating she could not remember because she was
tired. Youth A requested a bandage for her wrist, indicating
it was the only thing that will fix her pain. Youth A was
offered ibuprofen for pain as needed. The diagnosis was
documented as a “superficial injury of right wrist”.
• Behavior Management policy indicates that staff must have
ongoing, education, training, and demonstrated knowledge
of non-physical intervention and physical intervention,
Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI).
Analysis No violation was found as video review and interviews of youth
and staff did not support the allegation that Staff 1 choked Youth
A.
Although Youth A had some marks on her biceps and wrists, it
was determined that staff were not aggressive with her. The cause
of the marks was indeterminate and may have been due to Youth
A’s physically aggressive behavior, Youth A struggling to break
free from staff during a standing hold, the restraint by law
enforcement, or transportation to the hospital by law enforcement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Behavior management
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
12

system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all youth, their
families, and referring agencies.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff improperly restrained youth, causing scratches and bruises.
Investigation Interviews:
During the course of the investigation, Staff 1 admitted to holding
Youth A’s wrists, to prevent her from throwing items. Staff 1 also
reported holding Youth A by the back of the neck to prevent her
from biting. Staff 1 stated that she was aware these were not CPI
approved restraint techniques. Staff 1 also reported she was
immediately corrected by other staff and asked to step away.
This information was confirmed during interviews with Staff 6 and
Staff 8.
Video reviewed:
• Video from 8/10/24 was reviewed. The video was
consistent with information reported by staff. However, it
was difficult to fully see the interaction between Youth A
and Staff 1 due to the video quality.
The video did not show a restraint of Youth B, or staff
pushing her into a room.
The video showed Youth D in her room with staff, with the
door ajar.
• A second video of the wing was reviewed. This video was
filmed during the time Law Enforcement was there. The
video was very dark which made it difficult to see
specifically what occurred. However, it was noted that
officers restrained youth to the ground.
Documents reviewed
• CPI training materials were reviewed. Holding the youth’s
wrists and holding the back of youth’s neck are not
identified as interventions in CPI and therefore not
approved techniques.
• Behavior Management policy indicates that staff must have
ongoing, education, training, and demonstrated knowledge
of non-physical intervention and physical intervention,
Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI).
Analysis The facility is found to be in violation based on interviews, video
review, and an admission by Staff 1 that she did not follow CPI
training.
